questions.prompt: This adjective precedes "England" in the name of an upper-class Tory group led by Benjamin Disraeli [diz-"RAIL"-ee].  For 10 points each-

A.question: When applied to the word "Turks," what adjective identifies an early 20th-century reform movement in the Ottoman Empire?
A.answer: young (or jön; accept Young England or Young Turks or Jön Turkler)

B.question: This man founded the Young Italy movement in 1831, and fomented many democratic revolts intended to promote Italian unification.

C.question: The Young Bosnia [BAHZ-nee-uh] movement included Gavrilo Princip [GAHV-rih-loh "PRINT-sip"], who assassinated this Austrian archduke to ignite World War I.
C.answer: Archduke Franz Ferdinand (or Francis Ferdinand; prompt on partial answers)

questions.prompt: Pencil and paper ready.  Consider a game in which players have a one -third chance of winning 10 dollars [pause] and a two-thirds chance of losing 4 dollars.  For 10 points each -

A.question: If the game is played once, what is the expected value, in dollars, of the winnings?  You have 10 seconds.

B.question: Given each turn has an expected profit of 2/3 of a dollar, what is the total expected profit after 15 games?

C.question: As the total amount of money depends only on the state after the previous game, the game can be described by models named for what Russian mathematician?
C.answer: Andrey (Andreyevich) Markov ["MARK-off"] (accept discrete-time Markov process(es) or Markov chains or Markov models; prompt on "Markovian (processes or chains or models)")

questions.prompt: In 2018 accountant Scott Foster briefly became a celebrity for playing this position in a game.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this sports position played by emergency fill-in David Ayres in a February 2020 game after two players for the Carolina Hurricanes were injured.
A.answer: goalie(s) (or hockey goalies or hockey goaltenders)

B.question: The Hurricanes were playing on the road in this team's Scotiabank [SKOH-shuh-bank] Arena.  This hockey team's rivalry with the Canadiens [kuh-nay-dee-ENZ] is the oldest in NHL history.
B.answer: Toronto Maple Leafs (accept either underlined portion)

C.question: The Maple Leafs have won this NHL championship trophy 13 times, second only to the Canadiens.
C.answer: Stanley Cup (or La Coupe Stanley; accept Lord Stanley's Cup)

questions.prompt: In 2014 this state elected its first female senator, the Republican Shelley Moore Capito ["CAP"-ih-"toe"].  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this mountainous state with a politically influential coal industry.
A.answer: West Virginia (accept WV ["W-V"])

B.question: In his 2022 State of the State address, this West Virginia governor lifted up his pet bulldog, and told actress Bette [bet] Midler to "kiss" the dog's "hiney" ["HI"-nee].
B.answer: Jim Justice (or James Conley Justice II)

C.question: Midler had insulted West Virginia in a tweet criticizing this Democratic senator.  Protesters have paddled kayaks [KYE-yaks] to the houseboat of this man, who opposes most of the Build Back Better legislation.

questions.prompt: This codeword indicated a successful ambush, but is frequently mistranslated as "tiger."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Give this Japanese word repeated three times in the title of a 1970 film about the attack on Pearl Harbor.
A.answer: tora [toh-rah] (accept Tora! Tora! Tora!) ["Tora" is a homophone for the Japanese word for tiger.]

B.question: In the film Tora! Tora! Tora!, this leader of the Japanese Imperial Navy says that Japan has "awakened a sleeping giant," a quote invented for the film.
B.answer: Isoroku Yamamoto [ee-soh-roh-koo yah-mah-moh-toh] (or Isoroku Takano; accept names in either order; accept Admiral Yamamoto or Admiral Takano)

C.question: Tora! Tora! Tora! includes anachronistic [uh-nak-ruh-NISS-tik] shots of a Pearl Harbor memorial on this Hawaiian island, where the attack took place.

questions.prompt: Characters in this "Super Soul Musical" sing "Ease On Down the Road" while traveling to the Emerald City.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Wicked witches are given the names "Evamean" [EH-vuh-"mean"] and "Evillene" ["EVIL"-leen] in what 1974 musical based on a novel by L. Frank Baum?
A.answer: The Wiz(: The Super Soul Musical "Wonderful Wizard of Oz") (do not accept or prompt on "The (Wonderful) Wizard of Oz")

B.question: In a 1978 film version of The Wiz, the Scarecrow was played by this singer, who would later release the album Thriller.

C.question: A 2015 live TV adaptation of The Wiz featured this rapper and actress as the title character.  This co -star of Girls Trip received an Oscar nomination for playing Mama Morton in Chicago.

questions.prompt: Miguel Alcubierre [mee-GHEL ahl-koo-bee-"AIR-ray"] proposed a device that would achieve this kind of motion.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Some relativistic ["relative"-ISS-tik] jets appear to move in what manner that exceeds a "universal limit"?
A.answer: faster-than-light or superluminal motion (accept FTL ["F-T-L"] motion or answers indicating above the speed of light; prompt on "warp (speed or motion)" or "(Alcubierre) warp (drive)")

B.question: A superluminal ["super"-loo-muh-nul] jet is produced by M87 ["M-eighty-seven"], one of these galaxies found on the left side of Hubble's tuning fork diagram.
B.answer: elliptical [uh-LIP-tih-kul] galaxies (or ellipticals; accept supergiant elliptical galaxies or ellipticals; prompt on "radio (galaxies)")

C.question: Apparent superluminal motion can also occur with this phenomenon, in which a delayed light signal arrives after being reflected.  A similar phenomenon occurs when sound reflects off a wall or distant mountain.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about detention of prisoners during the U.S. War on Terror:

A.question: Many detainees were held at a camp on this naval base in Cuba, which the U.S. has leased since 1903.
A.answer: Guantánamo [gwahn-TAH-nah-moh] Bay (accept GTMO or Gitmo; accept Guantanamo Bay Naval Base or Naval Station Guantanamo Bay)

B.question: This British international spy agency aided the CIA in performing "extraordinary renditions" of detainees to "black sites," where the detainees were interrogated and tortured.
B.answer: MI6 ["M-I-six"] (accept Secret Intelligence Service or SIS)

C.question: One suspected CIA black site was on Diego Garcia [dee-AY-goh gar-SEE-uh], an isolated atoll [AT-tohl] in the middle of this ocean.  U.S. forces buried Osama bin Laden [oh-SAH-muh bin LAH-den] at sea in this ocean.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about Johann Wolfgang von Goethe [GUR-tuh]:

A.question: Goethe's magnum opus [OH-puss] is a tragedy about this scholar, who wagers his soul with the demon Mephistopheles [MEH-fih-STAH-fuh-leez].
A.answer: Heinrich Faust [fowst] (accept either underlined portion; accept Doctor Faust or Faustus; accept Henry Faust; accept Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy or Faust. Der Tragödie erster Teil or Faust: The Second Part of the Tragedy or Faust. Der Tragödie zweiter Teil in fünf Akten)

B.question: Goethe rose to fame with a 1774 novel about the "sorrows" of this young man, which are caused by his unrequited love for his friend Charlotte [shar-LOH-teh].
B.answer: (Young) Werther [VAIR-tair] (accept The Sorrows of Young Werther or Die Leiden des jungen Werthers)

C.question: Goethe's poetry collection West-Eastern Divan [dih-VAN] was inspired by the works of Hafez [HAH-fiz], who wrote many poems called ghazals [GAH-zahlz] in this language also used by the poet Rumi [ROO-mee].

questions.prompt: In circuit diagrams, this point is represented by three parallel lines of decreasing length.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this point in a circuit that serves as an infinite charge sink.
A.answer: ground (accept answers indicating where the circuit is grounded)

B.question: Some antennae [an-TEN-ee] that transmit these waves need to be grounded to prevent a buildup of charge.  These waves are often AM ["A-M"] or FM ["F-M"].

C.question: The ground node is typically defined to have a value of zero for this quantity.  The sum  of this quantity across all circuit elements in a loop equals zero by Kirchhoff's [KEER-kawf's] loop law.
C.answer: voltage (or electric potential; accept volts; do not accept or prompt on "(electric) potential energy")

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer these questions about intervals:

A.question: What interval exists between a given note and the next higher note with the same letter name, such as C to C?
A.answer: octave(s) [AHK-tiv]

B.question: What term describes intervals such as octaves, fourths, and fifths, whose pitches have small whole -number frequency ratios?
B.answer: perfect intervals (accept consonant ["CON"-suh-nunt] intervals or consonance)

C.question: This adjective describes intervals such as C to F-sharp, or D to G-sharp, that are one half-step larger than a perfect interval.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these people who contracted polio [POH-lee-oh]:

A.question: This future president was paralyzed from the waist down in 1921 from what doctors believed to be polio.
A.answer: Franklin D(elano) Roosevelt (or FDR; prompt on "Roosevelt")

B.question: Because of polio, this artist's right leg was shorter than her left.  Her works include a Self-portrait on the Borderline Between Mexico and the United States.
B.answer: Frida Kahlo [FREE-dah KAH-loh] de Rivera (or Magdalena Carmen Frieda Kahlo y Calderón)

C.question: This Israeli-American violinist plays sitting down because he contracted polio at age four.  He recorded the theme for the film Schindler's List.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about Solway [SUL-way] Firth:

A.question: Like the Dee and the Ribble estuaries [ESS-choo-air-eez], Solway Firth is an inlet of this sea.
A.answer: Irish Sea

B.question: To the north of Solway Firth is Dumfries [dum-"freeze"] and Galloway, a region of this constituent [kun-"STITCH"-oo-ent] country of the U.K.
B.answer: Scotland (or Kingdom of Scotland or Rioghachd na h-Alba)

C.question: Solway Firth is near this self-governing island.  A breed of cat named after this island's residents has an unusually short tail.
C.answer: Isle of Man (or Mann or Mannin or Ellan Vannin; prompt on "Manx (cat)")

questions.prompt: This story is set during a period when an "elf-queen" danced "in many a green meadow."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this story about a man who avoids execution by discovering what women most desire.
A.answer: The Wife of Bath's Tale (or The Tale of the Wyf of Bathe; prompt on "(The) Canterbury Tales")

B.question: "The Wife of Bath's Tale" is one of the Canterbury Tales written in Middle English by this author.

C.question: A digression in "The Wife of Bath's Tale" recounts a story about a tattletale wife from this Roman author's Metamorphoses [met-uh-MOR-fuh-seez].

questions.prompt: In 2020 protesters in the U.K. city of Bristol [BRISS-tul] tore down a statue of Edward Colston ["COAL-stun"] because of Colston's connection to this practice.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this practice, which often involved taking Africans across the Mid dle Passage.
A.answer: slavery (accept any answer indicating the holding of slaves or enslavement or human chattel or treating humans as property; accept the slave trade)

B.question: After the statue was toppled, white supremacists in Bristol vandalized the grave of an enslaved man with this name, which was shared by the Roman general who defeated Hannibal [HAN-uh-bul] at Zama [ZAH-muh].

C.question: This Whig who represented Bristol in Parliament introduced a bill to ban slaveowners from sitting in the House of Commons.  He criticized revolutionaries in Reflections on the Revolution in France.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about brown algae [AL-jee]:

A.question: Brown algae get their color from fucoxanthin ["FEW"-koh-ZAN-thin], a pigment also found in these tiny algae whose cell walls are made of silica [SIL-ih-kuh].
A.answer: diatoms [DYE-uh-tahm] (or Bacillariophyceae or Diatomea or Diatomophyceae or Bacillariae or Bacillariophyta)

B.question: In brown algae, this organelle ["organ"-EL] has four membranes instead of two.  The Calvin Cycle occurs in the fluid-filled stroma [STROH-muh] of this organelle.

C.question: This group of brown algae seaweeds are densely concentrated in underwater "forests."
C.answer: kelp(s) (or Laminariales; accept giant kelps or kelp forests)

questions.prompt: Floods in this country's KwaZulu-Natal [kwah-ZOO-loo nuh-TAHL] province killed over 400 people in 2022.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this country that has been governed by the African National Congress since 1994.
A.answer: South Africa (or Republic of South Africa; prompt on "RSA")

B.question: KwaZulu-Natal is the birthplace of this former South African president, who left office in 2018 and is facing an upcoming corruption trial.

C.question: Zuma's trial is connected to a 1990s contract that supplied South Africa with these weapons.  The Saab JAS 39 Gripen [sahb "J-A-S thirty-nine" GRIP-en] and the BAE ["B-A-E"] Hawk are examples of these weapons.
C.answer: fighter jets (or fighters or military aircraft or airplanes; accept any underlined portion)

questions.prompt: During the 1950s this man worked as a motivational speaker for General Electric.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this man who first made a political impression by giving the 1964 speech "A Time for Choosi ng" in support of Barry Goldwater.
A.answer: Ronald (Wilson) Reagan

B.question: In 1966 Reagan was elected governor of this West Coast state.

C.question: In the California governor's race, Reagan defeated Pat, a man with this surname.  Pat's son, who also had this surname, was governor of California in both the 1970s and 2010s.
C.answer: Brown (accept Browns; accept Pat Brown or Edmund Gerald Brown Sr. or Jerry Brown or Edmund Gerald Brown Jr.)

questions.prompt: This island contains the city of Hagåtña [huh-GAHT-n'yuh], whose name derives from a Chamorro [chuh-MOR-oh] word for "blood."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Andersen Air Force Base is on what Micronesian ["micro"-NEE-zhun] island controlled by the U.S.?
A.answer: Guam [gwahm] (or Guåhan)

B.question: Guam is part of these islands, which form the Philippine [FIL-uh-peen] Sea's eastern border with the greater Pacific Ocean.

C.question: The "brown tree" variety of these reptiles is an invasive species that has devastated Guam's birdli fe.  The "sea" types of these animals are sometimes mistaken for eels.
C.answer: snakes (or Serpentes; accept serpents; accept brown tree snakes or sea snakes or sea serpents)

questions.prompt: This title character feels "elephantishly ["elephant"-ish-lee] uneasy" while listening to the marital woes of Paul Riesling [REESS-ling].  For 10 points each -

A.question: What realtor from the city of Zenith [ZEE-nith] briefly becomes a rebel, and supports the socialist Seneca Doane [SEN-uh-kuh DOHN]?
A.answer: George F(ollansbee) Babbitt (accept either underlined portion)

B.question: This American author of Main Street parodied mindless "boosterism" ["BOOSTER"-ih-zum] in his 1922 novel Babbitt.

C.question: Lewis also wrote this novel about the fascist Buzz Windrip, who is elected president of the U.S.  Sales of this novel surged after the election of Donald Trump.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer these questions about theoretical "shells":

A.question: What structures have a "shell model" that predicts "magic numbers" of component particles -such as 2 and 82-that make these structures especially stable?
A.answer: atomic nuclei [NOO-klee-"eye"] (or atomic nucleus; accept nuclear shell model; do not accept or prompt on "atom(s)")

B.question: For volumes of revolution, the shell method and disk method are two ways of setting up what operation to calculate those volumes?
B.answer: volume integration (or volume integrals [IN-tug-rulz]; accept definite integrals or definite integration; accept answers indicating a function is integrated)

C.question: Isaac Newton proved that a spherically symmetric [sim-"metric"] shell exerts zero of what force on objects inside of it?  Newton derived this force's inverse -square law.
C.answer: gravity or gravitational force (accept (Newton's) law of universal gravitation)

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about Mexico in World War II:

A.question: Mexico entered the war in 1942, after two Mexican tankers were sunk by this type of German ship.
A.answer: U-boats (accept submarines or Unterseeboote)

B.question: A Mexican flying squadron that saw action in the Philippines [FIL-uh-peenz] was named after the Eagle warriors of this empire, which fought Hernán Cortés ["air"-NAHN kor-TEZ] in the early 16th century.
B.answer: Aztec Empire or Aztecs (or aztecas or Aztec Triple Alliance; accept Aztec Eagles or Águilas Aztecas; accept Tenochcas [teh-NOHCH-kuz] or Excan Tlahtoloyan)

C.question: During World War II Mexico was governed by a predecessor to this political party.  This party and its predecessors held national power between 1929 and 2000.
C.answer: PRI [pree or "P-R-I"] (or Institutional Revolutionary Party or Partido Revolucionario Institucional) [The PRI's predecessors were the National Revolutionary Party, which existed from 1929 to 1938, and the Party of the Mexican Revolution, which was replaced by the PRI in 1946.]

questions.prompt: This author wrote "old time is still a-flying" in a poem that warns "having lost but once your prime / you may forever tarry."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this 17th-century British poet who advised "gather ye rosebuds while ye may" in "To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time."
A.answer: Robert Herrick

B.question: "To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time" is a poem in this genre [ZHAHN-ruh], whose two-word Latin name means "seize the day."

C.question: Herrick's contemporary Andrew Marvell ["mar"-VEL] wrote this carpe diem poem that describes "Time's wingèd chariot hurrying near."
